utterances: And now here I am today not a successful comedian, but I've had, you know, a nice little fan base that has built around me in Alabama, oddly enough Alabama.
Kind of scary.
And do you still is the core of your humor still to make fun of yourself?
Sort of.
I like to do I do a character who's based sort of on the old sort of, you know, he's kind of based in the rat-pack era.
His name's Vick Trickinosis(ph).
And he's a self-deprecating comic who's also an insult comic.
So as much as he insults himself, he'll insult the audience right back.
But it's always on, you know, it's always on him.
So Don Rickles on Zoloft, maybe.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right, exactly, exactly.
You know, and for about six months, I had my own show at a local bar in Tuscaloosa, and one time I opened for Vick as myself.
And the room did not laugh.

But then when I came out as Vick, you know, people had you know, there was a word of mouth, and people knew I was Vick, and I came out there, and I sat there and made fun of myself as the opening act...
Oh, that's funny.
...and everyone loved it.
Oh, that's great.
That's kind of Andy Kaufman-like.
Andy Kaufman did that, yeah.
Yeah.
Except we were never quite sure some of the time.
Never, never, not until he died and was gone, for sure.
That's great.
Henri, good luck to you.
Oh, well, thank you, thank you.
Okay, we're going to give somebody else a chance.
That was fun.
Yeah, he's good.
Let's go to Daniel(ph), Daniel with us from Syracuse.
Yeah, how are you doing?
Thanks for having me.
Sure, go ahead.
Yeah, I just wanted to say I've been a comedian in New York City for six years, and I grew up kind of a class clown.
It really depended which class I was in.
But I was a drummer for a long period of time, and I didn't want to rely on the musical accompaniment of other people.
As a drummer, you can't just go out and play a drum solo for three hours.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So I had to go out and find a different craft, and I'd always had an affinity for stand-up comedy.
So I started writing a lot by learning how to write joke structure, by watching sitcoms and a lot of, like, Rodney Dangerfield.
Because there's different types of jokes.
There's set-up punch jokes, and then there's character-driven comedy, which is more Robin Williams-type.
Right.
Marlo Thomas, I was fascinated again in your interview with Jerry Seinfeld where he talked about, you know, there's no such it's all observational humor.
There's no such thing as observational humor, per se.
But the way he described you, you know, taking the lost sock routine.
Right, the anatomy of a joke.

What I think is interesting, too, and especially as we listen to these three different comedians from around the country, and they all have a different style, I said to Jerry Seinfeld, it's interesting to me since I grew up with George Burns and Bob Hope and my dad and all these guys, and they were all so different.
And Jerry said, you know, he said comedy is like a perfume counter.
You go to the perfume counter, and you try these little tester bottles, and you don't like all the perfumes.
There's just one or two that really is your style.
He said, and comedy's like that.
There's no rhyme or reason as to why one perfume smells better to you than another one.
And there's no rhyme or reason why one comic is completely your style, and another one isn't.
And I found that really fascinating.

The most poignant thing that I found Jerry Seinfeld to say is that stand-up comedy is not a monologue, it's a dialogue because the laughter is as important as the monologue itself because laughter has different sizes and shapes and sounds and tones to it.
And you have to be able to create that conversation as fluidly as possible.
And that's when you become a good comic, when you're creating a dialogue rather than a monologue.
That's a great point.
I can't imagine, like, being a monologist and rehearsing by yourself.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You really need to hear somebody laugh at it.
That's great.
I mean, there's no way to rehearse comedy.
I mean, if you're not going on stage nightly, you're not exercising the ability to create that dialogue.
So it's really a necessity to be on stage.
Jay Leno said, I asked him why do you you have a show every night, why in God's name do you need to do 160 nightclub dates a year?
He said it's different.
He said if you're not out there doing it, you will forget it.
Theres a certain thing that you must continue to practice.
Yeah, you have to stay sharp.
Absolutely.
And then Seinfeld said if you're good at comedy - if you're good at stand-up, that doesn't mean you're going to be good at anything else.
And if you're good at anything else, that doesn't mean you're going to be good at stand-up.
We didn't hear from him for two years.
He kind of disappeared.
And two years later, we saw this guy, this brilliant, brilliant comedian named George Carlin.
And that's when Jerry said, you see, doing one thing does not mean you can do the other thing well.
It's a completely different art.
Daniel....

It is, and I find that it just because you're naturally funny, like some of the people that in social situations tend to be the funniest people can't always translate that to the stage because it's really a different ballgame.
Completely.
Some can.
Some can't.
Well, it's also easy to be naturally funny once.
It's hard to do it every night.
Exactly.
Daniel, thanks very much for the call, good luck to you.
Yeah, thanks a lot.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can go next to Dorothy(ph), Dorothy with us from Jacksonville.
Yes, hello, thank you.
I just wanted to say, Marlo, this is Dorothy Pittman-Hughes(ph).
Oh, hi Dorothy.
Wow, how exciting.
It's so wonderful to hear you.
And I'm in Jacksonville, Florida, have a bookstore.
I'm calling for your book immediately for my store.
Oh, you're going to love it.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
That's great.
Great to hear from you.
